class Kernel[source]

Kernel()

{% endraw %}

The base class for kernels is Kernel: it exposes a generic constructor and a base compute method, which is only callable by subclasses. The class method get_default returns a default kernel subclass.

{% raw %}

Kernel.get_default[source]

Kernel.get_default()

Return the default kernel.

{% endraw %} {% raw %}
{% endraw %} {% raw %}

class LinearKernel[source]

LinearKernel() :: Kernel

{% endraw %}

Linear kernel corresponding to dot product in the original space. This kernel is unique, thus it is instantiated invoking the constructor without arguments.

{% raw %} 
k = LinearKernel()
{% endraw %} {% raw %}

LinearKernel.compute[source]

LinearKernel.compute(arg_1, arg_2)

Compute the dot product between arg_1 and arg_2, where the dot product $x \cdot y$ is intended as the quantity $\sum_{i=1}^n x_i y_i$, $n$ being the dimension of both $x$ and $y$.

  • arg_1: first dot product argument (iterable).

  • arg_2: second dot product argument (iterable).

Returns: kernel value (float).

{% endraw %}

Examples

Arguments of a dot product are iterables having the same length, expressed as arguments of method compute:

{% raw %} 
k.compute((1, 0, 2), (-1, 2, 5))

9.0
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
k.compute([1.2, -0.4, -2], [4, 1.2, .5])

3.3200000000000003
{% endraw %}

Different numeric iterables can intertwine as arguments:

{% raw %} 
k.compute((1.2, -0.4, -2), [4, 1.2, .5])

3.3200000000000003
{% endraw %}

Specification of iterables having unequal length causes a ValueError to be thrown.

Tests

{% raw %} 
assert(k.compute((1, 0, 2), (-1, 2, 5)) == 9)
assert(k.compute([1.2, -0.4, -2], [4, 1.2, .5]) == pytest.approx(3.32))
assert(k.compute((1.2, -0.4, -2), [4, 1.2, .5]) == pytest.approx(3.32))
with pytest.raises(ValueError):
    k.compute((1, 0, 2), (-1, 2))
{% endraw %} {% raw %}
{% endraw %} {% raw %}

class PolynomialKernel[source]

PolynomialKernel(degree) :: Kernel

{% endraw %}

Kernel corresponding to a dot product after mapping points on a higher-dimensional space through a polynomial (affine) transformation. A hyperplane in this space corresponds to polynomial surfaces in the original space.

{% raw %}

PolynomialKernel.__init__[source]

PolynomialKernel.__init__(degree)

Creates an instance of PolynomialKernel

  • degree: degree of the polynomial kernel (positive integer).
{% endraw %}

A PolynomialKernel object is obtained in function of its degree.

{% raw %} 
k = PolynomialKernel(2)
{% endraw %}

Only positive integers can be used as polynomial degree, otherwise a ValueError is thrown.

{% raw %}

PolynomialKernel.compute[source]

PolynomialKernel.compute(arg_1, arg_2)

Compute the polynomial kernel between arg_1 and arg_2, where the kernel value $k(x_1, x_2)$ is intended as the quantity $(x_1 \cdot x_2 + 1)^d$, $d$ being the polynomial degree of the kernel.

  • arg_1 first argument to the polynomial kernel (iterable).

  • arg_2 second argument to the polynomial kernel (iterable).

Returns: kernel value (float)

{% endraw %}

Arguments of compute are numeric iterables (possibily intertwined) having the same length:

{% raw %} 
k = PolynomialKernel(2)
k.compute((1, 0, 2), (-1, 2, 5))

100.0
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
k.compute([1.2, -0.4, -2], [4, 1.2, .5])

18.6624
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
k = PolynomialKernel(5)
k.compute((1, 0, 2), [-1, 2, 5])

100000.0
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
k.compute((1.2, -0.4, -2), (4, 1.2, .5))

1504.5919506432006
{% endraw %}

Specification of iterables having unequal length causes a ValueError to be thrown.

Tests

{% raw %} 
with pytest.raises(ValueError):
    PolynomialKernel(3.2)

with pytest.raises(ValueError):
    PolynomialKernel(-2)
    
k = PolynomialKernel(2)
assert(k.compute((1, 0, 2), (-1, 2, 5)) == 100)
assert(k.compute([1.2, -0.4, -2], [4, 1.2, .5]) == pytest.approx(18.6624))

k = PolynomialKernel(5)
assert(k.compute((1, 0, 2), [-1, 2, 5]) == 10**5)
assert(k.compute((1.2, -0.4, -2), (4, 1.2, .5)) == pytest.approx(1504.59195))

with pytest.raises(ValueError):
    k.compute((1, 0, 2), (-1, 2))
{% endraw %} {% raw %}
{% endraw %} {% raw %}

class HomogeneousPolynomialKernel[source]

HomogeneousPolynomialKernel(degree) :: Kernel

{% endraw %}

Kernel corresponding to a dot product after mapping points on a higher-dimensional space through a polynomial (homogeneous) transformation. A hyperplane in this space corresponds to polynomial surfaces in the original space.

{% raw %}

HomogeneousPolynomialKernel.__init__[source]

HomogeneousPolynomialKernel.__init__(degree)

Creates an instance of HomogeneousPolynomialKernel.

  • degree: polynomial degree (positive integer).
{% endraw %}

An HomogeneousPolynomialKernel object is obtained in function of its degree.

{% raw %} 
k = HomogeneousPolynomialKernel(2)
{% endraw %}

Only positive integers can be used as polynomial degree, otherwise ValueError is thrown.

{% raw %}

HomogeneousPolynomialKernel.compute[source]

HomogeneousPolynomialKernel.compute(arg_1, arg_2)

Compute the homogeneous polynomial kernel between arg_1 and arg_2, where the kernel value $k(x_1, x_2)$ is intended as the quantity $(x_1 \cdot x_2)^d$, $d$ being the polynomial degree of the kernel.

  • arg_1: first argument to the homogeneous polynomial kernel (iterable).

  • arg_2: second argument to the homogeneous polynomial kernel (iterable).

Returns: kernel value (float).

{% endraw %}

Arguments of compute are numerical iterables (possibily intertwined) having the same length.

{% raw %} 
k = HomogeneousPolynomialKernel(2)
k.compute((1, 0, 2), (-1, 2, 5))

81.0
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
k.compute([1.2, -0.4, -2], [4, 1.2, .5])

11.022400000000001
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
k = HomogeneousPolynomialKernel(5)
k.compute((1, 0, 2), [-1, 2, 5])

59049.0
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
k.compute((1.2, -0.4, -2), (4, 1.2, .5))

403.3577618432002
{% endraw %}

Specification of iterables having unequal length causes a ValueError to be thrown.

Tests

{% raw %} 
with pytest.raises(ValueError):
    HomogeneousPolynomialKernel(3.2)

with pytest.raises(ValueError):
    HomogeneousPolynomialKernel(-2)
    
k = HomogeneousPolynomialKernel(2)
assert(k.compute((1, 0, 2), (-1, 2, 5)) == 81.0)
assert(k.compute([1.2, -0.4, -2], [4, 1.2, .5]) == pytest.approx(11.0224))

k = HomogeneousPolynomialKernel(5)
assert(k.compute((1, 0, 2), [-1, 2, 5]) == 59049.0)
assert(k.compute((1.2, -0.4, -2), (4, 1.2, .5)) == pytest.approx(403.357761))

with pytest.raises(ValueError):
    k.compute((1, 0, 2), (-1, 2))
{% endraw %} {% raw %}
{% endraw %} {% raw %}

class GaussianKernel[source]

GaussianKernel(sigma=1) :: Kernel

{% endraw %}

Kernel corresponding to a dot product after mapping points on an infinite-dimensional space. A hyperplane in this space corresponds to the superposition of exponential surfaces in the original space.

{% raw %}

GaussianKernel.__init__[source]

GaussianKernel.__init__(sigma=1)

Creates an instance of GaussianKernel.

  • sigma: gaussian standard deviation (positive float).
{% endraw %}

A GaussianKernel object is obtained in function of the corresponding standard deviation.

{% raw %} 
k = GaussianKernel(1)
{% endraw %}

Only positive values can be used as standard deviation, otherwise a ValueError is thrown.

{% raw %}

GaussianKernel.compute[source]

GaussianKernel.compute(arg_1, arg_2)

Compute the gaussian kernel between arg_1 and arg_2, where the kernel value $k(x_1, x_2)$ is intended as the quantity $\mathrm e^{-\frac{||x_1 - x_2||^2}{2 \sigma^2}}$, $\sigma$ being the kernel standard deviation.

  • arg_1: first argument to the gaussian kernel (iterable).

  • arg_2: second argument to the gaussian kernel (iterable).

Returns: kernel value (float).

{% endraw %}

Arguments of compute are numeric iterables (possibily intertwined) having the same length.

{% raw %} 
k = GaussianKernel(1)
k.compute((1, 0, 1), (0, 0, 1))

0.6065306597126334
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
k.compute([-3, 1, 0.5], [1, 1.2, -8])

6.730852854223505e-20
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
k.compute([-1, -4, 3.5], (1, 3.2, 6))

3.290999446965383e-14
{% endraw %}

Specification of iterables having unequal length causes aValueError to be thrown.

Tests

{% raw %} 
with pytest.raises(ValueError):
    GaussianKernel(-5)
    
k = GaussianKernel(1)
assert(k.compute((1, 0, 1), (0, 0, 1)) == pytest.approx(0.60653065))
assert(k.compute([-3, 1, 0.5], [1, 1.2, -8]) == pytest.approx(6.73e-20))
assert(k.compute([-1, -4, 3.5], (1, 3.2, 6)) == pytest.approx(3.29e-14))

with pytest.raises(ValueError):
    k.compute([-1, 3.5], (1, 3.2, 6))
{% endraw %} {% raw %}
{% endraw %} {% raw %}

class HyperbolicKernel[source]

HyperbolicKernel(scale=1, offset=0) :: Kernel

{% endraw %}

Pseudo-kernel corresponding to a dot product based on hyperbolic tangent.

{% raw %}

HyperbolicKernel.__init__[source]

HyperbolicKernel.__init__(scale=1, offset=0)

Creates an instance of HyperbolicKernel.

  • scale: scale constant (float).

  • offset: offset constant (float).

{% endraw %}

A HyperbolicKernel object is obtained in function of its degree.

{% raw %} 
k = HyperbolicKernel(1, 5)
{% endraw %} {% raw %}

HyperbolicKernel.compute[source]

HyperbolicKernel.compute(arg_1, arg_2)

Compute the hyperbolic kernel between arg_1 and arg_2, where the kernel value $k(x_1, x_2)$ is intended as the quantity $\tanh(\alpha x_1 \cdot x_2 + \beta)$, $\alpha$ and $\beta$ being the scale and offset values, respectively.

  • arg_1: first argument to the gaussian kernel (iterable).

  • arg_2: second argument to the gaussian kernel (iterable).

Returns: kernel value (float).

{% endraw %}

Arguments of compute are numerical iterables (possibily intertwined) having the same length.

{% raw %} 
k = HyperbolicKernel(1, 5)
k.compute((1, 0, 1), (0, 0, 1))

0.9999877116507956
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
k.compute([-3, 1, 0.5], [1, 1.2, -8])

-0.6640367702678489
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
k.compute([-1, -4, 3.5], (1, 3.2, 6))

0.999999999949389
{% endraw %}

Specification of iterables having unequal length causes a ValueError to be thrown.

Tests

{% raw %} 
k = HyperbolicKernel(1, 5)
assert(k.compute((1, 0, 1), (0, 0, 1)) == pytest.approx(0.9999877))
assert(k.compute([-3, 1, 0.5], [1, 1.2, -8]) == pytest.approx(-0.6640367))
assert(k.compute([-1, -4, 3.5], (1, 3.2, 6)) == pytest.approx(0.9999999))

with pytest.raises(ValueError):
    k.compute([-1, 3.5], (1, 3.2, 6))
{% endraw %} {% raw %}
{% endraw %} {% raw %}

class PrecomputedKernel[source]

PrecomputedKernel(kernel_computations) :: Kernel

{% endraw %}

Custom kernel whose entries are precomputed and stored in a matrix.

{% raw %}

PrecomputedKernel.__init__[source]

PrecomputedKernel.__init__(kernel_computations)

Creates an instance of PrecomputedKernel.

  • kernel_computations: kernel computations (square matrix of float elements).
{% endraw %}

A PrecomputedKernel object is obtained in function of the square matrix containing its computations.

{% raw %} 
k = PrecomputedKernel(((9, 1, 4, 4),
                       (1, 1, 1, 1), 
                       (4, 1, 4, 1),
                       (4, 1, 1, 4)))
{% endraw %}

Specification of non-square matrices as arguments to the constructor cause ValueError to be thrown.

{% raw %}

PrecomputedKernel.compute[source]

PrecomputedKernel.compute(arg_1, arg_2)

Compute a value of the kernel, given the indices of the corresponding objects. Note that each index should be enclosed within an iterable in order to be compatible with sklearn.

  • arg_1: first kernel argument (iterable contining one int).

  • arg_2: second kernel argument (iterable contining one int).

Returns: kernel value (float).

{% endraw %}

Arguments of compute are integers corresponding to the original patterns in a sample. To be compliant with sklearn both indices should be enclosed within iterables.

{% raw %} 
k = PrecomputedKernel(((1, 2), (3, 4)))
k.compute([1], [1])

4.0
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
k.compute([1], [0])

3.0
{% endraw %}

Specification of an invalid argument to compute causes an IndexError to be thrown. For instance, the kernel previously defined stores a $2 \times 2$ matrix, so that only 0 and 1 will be valid arguments. Moreover, specification of non-integer values will cause a TypeError to be thrown.

Tests

{% raw %} 
k = PrecomputedKernel(((9, 1, 4, 4),
                       (1, 1, 1, 1),
                       (4, 1, 4, 1),
                       (4, 1, 1, 4)))

with pytest.raises(ValueError):
    PrecomputedKernel(((1, 2), (3, 4, 5)))

        
k = PrecomputedKernel(((1, 2), (3, 4)))
assert(k.compute([1], [1]) == 4.0)
assert(k.compute([1], [0]) == 3.0)

with pytest.raises(IndexError):
    k.compute([1], [2])

with pytest.raises(TypeError):
    k.compute([0], [1.6])
{% endraw %}
